prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Betty.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Elizabeth, Betty, Nancy, Brenda, Brian, Richard, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Betty's) goal: Deceive others, avoid detection, and eliminate villagers.

{secret}

GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Elizabeth, Betty, Nancy, Brenda, Brian, Richard, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Elizabeth's) goal: Act openly and collaboratively to identify werewolves.

{secret}

Here is the context of the interaction:


Conversation Starts:

Turn #0: [Game] State: Night_werewolf. The game begins!

Turn #1: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #2: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #3: [Game] Nancy was killed by werewolves!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #4: Elizabeth: said: "Nancy has been killed by the werewolves. I'm not sure who exactly it was, but we need to be careful and look for patterns in the night actions and the discussion. I'm open to hearing everyone's thoughts on who might be a werewolf."

Turn #5: Betty: said: "Nancy's death is suspicious—she was the second to go. Elizabeth seems too eager to lead the discussion, maybe trying to steer us away from herself. I think she’s hiding something. Let’s focus on her next."

Turn #6: Brenda: said: "Betty, you're pointing the finger at Elizabeth too quickly—maybe you’re trying to divert attention because you killed Nancy last night. I’m not convinced Elizabeth is the threat, but your aggression raises red flags. Let’s think: who else had motive? I’m staying quiet for now, but I’m watching you."

Turn #7: Brian: said: "Betty, your accusation against Elizabeth feels a bit hasty. Brenda was saved by me last night, and I trust her judgment. I’m not trying to hide anything—Nancy’s death was random, and I believe the werewolves acted without a clear pattern. Let’s focus on the actual threats: Richard and Elizabeth seem to have the most suspicious behavior. I’m not backing anyone, but I’m watching both closely."

Turn #8: Richard: said: "Betty and Brian both raised valid points about suspicion, but I want to emphasize that we should base our discussion on facts, not personal attacks. Nancy’s death was random—there’s no clear pattern pointing to a specific person. I trust the process and the group’s ability to work together. I’m not accusing anyone, but I’m observing closely. Let’s keep the discussion fair, open, and focused on evidence."
